Halloween Kills is officially 1 year old!!! Didnt get the best reception from fans and critics like the 2018 film  The director has explained his view on his film's criticism arguing that leaving certain plot points "unresolved" was intentional but perhaps not favorable to the audience Green admitted that the final film creates an opportunity to clean up the mess that was left over from the previous movie  CinenaSnob does point out the heavy flaws like the many scenes of speechifying, the legacy characters being illogical,  and going over stuff people already know  But I love this is still the most violent installment in the franchise  A bit of a step down yet  Michael Myers knows no bounds when it comes to killing  Love all the throwbacks to the 1978 movie, I'm amazed they had the gall to reference Halloween II (1981) Lots of ideas about mob mentality, challenging the system, and people coming together as a collective whole to stop the fear and violence shaking them  Not all of it is perfectly wound but John Carpenter, Danny McBride, and David Gordon Green still deliver the thrills  It's not just Laurie Strode's story now, it's the town of Haddonfield's story

Awful awful movie. They could have opened it like a flashback like they did in Halloween kills. Where Michael was a kid and u see him leaving for Halloween before killing his sister and his parents r saying goodbye. U see this from the perspective of behind his head. Then u c him say something 2 another kid but never hear it and the kid says no Michael thereby adding mystery. Then he kills his sister. Then it shifts to wen hes a teenager in the mental hospital. Again the perspective is from behind his head and we see sum awesome kills like a nurse getting stabbed in the nose and this is actually wer he gets his first mask which is strikingly similar to his original mask and we get to see teen Michael in a extremely similar looking mask. Then it shifts to the night Karen was apparently murdered and we see from his perspective how he entered the house and how he escaped. Its also revealed that karen just about survived her attack. Then it shifts to present day, a woman carving a pumpkin in present day. The day b4 Halloween. She puts knive on a shelf not noticing it falls. Then she is making decorations for Halloween and spills red paint which goes on the knive. Michael picks this up and it becomes his new improved trademark weapon becoming stained with blood over time. People should remember this; The cinematic effects used in Halloween became a Success for the entire slasher franchise. This was unique to the Halloween slasher series.  That concept - Someone who's personality traits is that of a psychopat, showing no remorse in his or her's actions, hiding their facial expression behind a mask; So you are not able to see what the individual is thinking, and or feeling. Add a sense of paleness mixed in with a bit of white - contrasts -  and you've got the perfect neutral facial expression that awakens the most basic fight or flight response in us when we see it.   ... Why?  Because you can't trust anyone who's facial expression is behind a mask - You don't know what they are up to. Is it good, or bad?   The storyline of their upbringing in a home with both psychological, and physical abuse due to alcohol and financial problems to shed some light on as to why they do what they do, is actually close to real life. It is based on real circumstances, it could happen, it has happened, and it will happen again.   Myers is not a God, he is not the devil either. He is man, just like me, and just like you.   That is what intrigue me,  about the Halloween series.

When there's no way a real human could live through all of the things he's lived through. I hated when they showed him with his mask off. Even though it never showed his face, it ruined the element of evil and mystery for me. I always wanted it to be discovered that he was possessed by the devil, or somehow had some sort of supernatural power. But seeing him at that insane asylum with no mask and bald head (and gray beard) just made him seem like a regular psychopath instead of a supernatural being like I always thought of him as being. If any of this even made sense.

Not gonna lie... After rewatching the original movie and the 2018 one. I kinda appreciate this movie a lot.  There's a lot of tie ins, references and call backs to the OG.  Like the old Nurse from the OG, the car scene she had in this movie was extremely reminiscent of her first encounter with him. I love that kinda shit.  Also, having Lindsey, Tommy and Lonnie - a kid who only had like 1 or two scenes in the OG being brought back. Felt cool to see.  Focusing on these characters made the world of Halloween seem bigger and imo it was kinda cool seeing the effect Micheal had on the town and the characters who did survive. I genuinely enjoyed seeing Tommy, Lindsey and Lonnie doing shit.  Highly reccommend seeing the OG before this movie. It really adds to it imo

And it's funny how the film, as the one before it, is painting Laurie as some Michael Myers expert when she only had a single encounter with him, and especially with him not being her brother now, it makes even less sense. They made the specific point of eliminating the sibling bond between Michael and Laurie....only to STILL have them tethered together. Halloween 2018 wasn't bad (in fact, I thought it was better than some of the other films), this one might be okay, but this is just growing....tiresome. I'm morbidly curious how the series would have turned out if they had done as Carpenter originally envisioned which was starting with Halloween III, the series would have become an anthology series, with a new film released every year around a different premise. Several townspeople begin floating into the sky, into the gaping maw of Pennywise.  Townspeople begin to run, but are cut down at the ankles by a tag team of Chucky, Chucky's Bride and Annabelle, who begin to evicerate them.  Park Benches begin to whirl into heads and faces begin to sluff off as the Poltergeist from Poltergeist lets loose.  As people are knocked unconscious by the debris, they are confronted in thier coma dreams by Freddy Kreuger, who begins to enact all kinds of tortures.  The square becomes a killzone of horrific traps and we cut to Jigsaw looking at the scene through CCTV cameras.  The Avengers music crescendos as our team coalesces, to stand before the carnage they have wrought on the town. The remaining townspeople are petrified.  Michael: *whispers* "this is the part, where you run away."  The town flees and the group scatters to continue preying upon them.

I met him, 15 years ago; I was told there was nothing left; no reason, no conscience, no understanding in even the most rudimentary sense of life or death, of good or evil, right or wrong. I met this... six-year-old child with this blank, pale, emotionless face, and... the blackest eyes - the Devil's eyes. I spent eight years trying to reach him, and then another seven trying to keep him locked up, because I realized that what was living behind that boy's eyes was purely and simply... evil.

The comment section illustrates an interesting twist, not only for the film, but society's perception in general.   The townsfolk are mindless psychopaths hunting down a severely traumatized  victim. You see Michael Myers was created by bullies, then bullied by those who incarcerated him, in what they conned Michael into as a safe space. As an adult, Michael escapes from his "safe space," looking for a fair tidbit of justice and his step sister. He merely wants to re-connect and sort a thing or two out. The townsfolk not only continue to deceive him, but they continue to hunt him down, tear him down with their hatefulness, and try to kill him. He was not even allowed to remain in his childhood home as his true safe space.  What the movie line fails to reveal are two credits to Michael's cause. Hopefully in the next installment Michael will get a fair shake and the true nature of Haddonfield will be revealed. Michael is a bisexual with gender dysphoria and he is in love with his step sister Laurie. What he is really dealing with are small town mindless psychopathic gun-toting homophobic sexists bent on destroying this poor soul. And if you think things couldn't get worse for Michael, the townsfolk are also very likely racist Trump supporting anti-vaxers. You can hardly blame Michael for having a grievance. Hopefully, he finally gets a fair shake.  I anticipate that the next installment will reveal these facts, and that we will see a Michael-Laurie romance, marriage, and little Michael-Laurie twins.

This series must have some record of most number of timelines branching from the first movie: -Halloween + Halloween 2 (Michael's original death) -Halloween + Halloween 2 (Michael somehow surviving) + Halloween 3/4/5/6 -Halloween + Halloween 2 + Halloween H20 (Michael's 2nd official death) *ignores Halloween 4/5/6* -Halloween + Halloween 2 + Halloween H20 (Michael survives due to stupid retcon) + Halloween Resurrection -Halloween + Halloween (2018) + Halloween Kills
I doubt it will be anywhere as good as Halloween 1, and 2 (yes the sequel from 81) which will always be the official two for me, but as it's own trilogy it could be an enjoyable three part movie series, 4 if you include the first, which I guess is part of these new movies.  I enjoyed Halloween 2018 for what it was, but apart from Micheal Myers (who was menacing, and looked great), and the music, I found it to be a decent, but uneven movie much like H20 was.  The sequel here seems to treat Michael as if he's Jason Voorhees slashing anything he encounters with gushing gore effects.    Like the 2018 movie, Halloween Kills seems to lift parts from other movies, like the hospital from 2, and the mob to kill Michael in 4.  Perhaps the movie will be entertaining enough, despite the recycled elements from other movies, but I'm not seeing much original stuff to make this new series stand on it's own merits.  I also get many people didn't like the direction of Halloween 2 (which I very much like), so if this new trilogy works for them great, regardless of how this trilogy ends, I'll always have the first two movies.

At night I saw shadows that moved.Â  I saw very scary faces on the walls, ceilings, floors...Many times I felt that someone evil was standing behind me, but when I would turn around, there would be no one standing. I was scared.Â Â  In my heart I decided to turn to God for help. I decided to fast and prayÂ  until God helped me. I turned off all entertainment. I only left my school books. In the morning and before bedtime I prayed, read the Bible, especially The New Testament part, memorized Bible verses that I liked. I fell asleep thinking about what I read.Â  Also I practiced reciting Bible verses in my head, until I would fall asleep.Â  I was not without food everyday, but fasted as much as I could. After some time, one night, Jesus Christ opened my bedroom door, walked in, and stood by the side of my bed.Â  I remember how I sat down in my bed and gasped: "Jesus!"Â  He looked very seriously, almost sternly around my room and became invisible.Â  And in one moment, everything that stalked me, just vanished forever from my life.Â  The dark, evil forces that watched me, disappeared.Â  It was a miracle! Halloween Kills: "evil dies tonight" Halloween Kills *Michael Myers dies in the end...but we don't see it*  5 Months Later  .......fasten your seatbelts....Michael's Backkkkkkkk  This looks good....but when does it get to a point when all tension is burned to a crisp and any and all impact is gone. I truly feel this should be the final Halloween movie. They've been on a fairly long and lucky streak with some good films...but after Kills...the tension, realistically....should be gone. You don't feel any sense of relief or victory for the protagonists in the end, because you know "they didn't show it...so there's got to be MORE". There's just no impact, when you know there's just gonna be another. It also makes the plot/formula VERY predictable. Some local murders happen, main character gears up, tries to fight it a few times, gets called crazy or fails a few times, end battle, 1v1 or 2v1 or 3v1, and then Michael dies....but we don't see it. That's just the whole formula.  This movie looks good, and like it will be enjoyable, like the previous film...but this has to be the end. Since it feels this will involve the town, maybe have the whole town come together and in the end, have everyone watching as Michael Myers finally dies, and Laurie, along with her others there too...the end.

You know, I have read several comments since this trailer was released 2 weeks ago, and among them they write things about the scene that escapes from Laurie's burning house like: "How was Michael able to kill all the firefighters at once if it's just one person?" or also "That is not possible to happen, it is unreal". Therefore, I made several theories about this scene:  1.- The firefighters were only notified to go to the house to put out the fire, perhaps because of the danger it symbolizes being near a forest, because of that, no one knew that Michael is trapped, or rather hidden, where I start the fire.  2.- Everyone outside was completely in shock and frozen when they saw Michael leave the house intact, since as Laurie mentioned: "No man can survive a fire", therefore, they were still processing what they saw being too late to act when Michael started murdering them.  3.- Even if all the firefighters were in a group against him, his anger, rage and hatred towards the town of Haddofield gave him the necessary fuel to kill each of them without problems, let's add that the stamina he uses to withstand the attacks that they perform against him; Also remember that Michael is not human, he is evil in person using the form of a man to kill anyone who sees and gets in his way as it is what he wants to do, kill for fun and whim.

God is a just judge therefore he cannot let sin go unpunished. The penalty for our sin is death. ( the second death is hell)   "For the wages of sin is death, but the free gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord." Romans 6:23  Now for the Good News ğŸ™‚  God/Jesus loves you. God loves you so much that he sent Jesus to die in your/my place so that we could be free from sin, and death (the second death a.k.a. hell). Jesus willingly took the punishment for us.  He was beat, wounded, humiliated, and killed for our faults. There's something that bugs me in this trailer. That guy with the map, the one who says following the paths of victims leads straight to Michael's home? That.....sounds off to me somehow.  Think about it; all this time Michael has been proven to have NO rhyme or reason to his killing. No pattern, no preferred targets, no psychological rituals to it. Just random murder, acts of pure evil. But for him to intentionally leave a path leading to his own home like that? It seems PLANNED to me somehow. I don't think going back home is his goal at all, just something he's tricking them into believing he has a pattern. Something they can predict.  Even with the whoile town hunting him down, Myers is still the hunter. And I think he's setting his trap.

Note on Rob zombie film: To take a movie whose whole plot is someone being evil just as they are evil and try explain with psychological study of their childhood misses the entire point of the movie. Add in it plays to the idea everyone is evil due to their childhood which is simply not true for some. They had good childhood and no trauma. Some have things in their childhood but so do others and they don't kill. But this whole storyline was about the people who don't and are evil. So making it something else was dumb. If that's what you want to do, make your own movie and call it something else.

How???? If he survived fire, it means he is born of fire, hence a demon has taken over the body. Only Michael's childhood memory remains from neglectful loved ones, an abusive stepfather and an entire town who knew the truth of his situation and did nothing about it. So his memory remains that of a vengeful spirit. Plot twist: Michaels soul is in hell and his torment grows worse with each kill. But he finally accepts his fate and forgives those who wronged him which renders the demon powerless and is finally able to be killed. All the while Michaels spirit communicates to Laurie and helps her track the demon down and dispose of him. Ending scene: as the demon is sent to hell, Michael grabs it and wraps it in chains and holds on to him as they both descend into the deepest and darkest parts of hell. The remaining family members and neighbors ask forgiveness for any part they had in neglecting Michael and forgive him. The sun rises on the town indicating the town has been cleansed. Just my rendition. Would love to see a horror movie that ends in forgiveness and redemption.

Just like in 2018 my abstinence from Facebook begins due to the fact there's a Halloween movie coming out within the next 4 months. I happen to be a huge fan of the Halloween franchise so I'm in all the groups. But these kids get on there and post all day long about every minute minuscule detail that they can find about the movie before it comes out. Every leaked trailer, leaked footage, photographs, every possible scenario of what's going to happen with every character, everything that they've heard. It's like guys I get you're fanboys but don't you want to watch the movie and not know what's going to happen? You guys have seriously got to get a life. The only thing that they have to respond with is "Don't look at it if you don't want to."  Thank you for that tremendous advice. I have no idea why I didn't think of that myself, it's not like it just pops up on my news feed every single post. Fruit baskets. I usually leave all of that alone because we all have something in common but how does every single one of you stand about five feet five, about 70 lb overweight with a huge gut, a huge beard, wear nothing but black t-shirts, and live in your mom's basement. It's absolutely mind-boggling how every single one of you can look exactly the same.

So I've already commented and made it clear that I seriously CANNOT wait for this movie - the 'Halloween' franchise is my #1 Horror Franchise (of all time) & my #3 Movie Franchise Overall (of all time) just behind #1-Star Wars & #2-DC (pre-Hamada aka DC prior to their new "woke" era). That being said I did raise a couple of issues I had specifically with the trailer, however those (trailer) issues have raised new concerns regarding the movie itself... I just realized nothing about the trailer was actually scary... so, I really, really hope I'm wrong but I'm guessing 'Kills' is going to be just like Halloween 2018 in the sense that we wouldn't have any problem watching it at night while home alone in the dark.  As for the 2 other issues I had specifically with the trailer (well, I guess it could be considered 1 issue technically) they were: 1) showing too much which seems to be the consensus & 2) including a shot that shows one of our beloved, & borderline iconic, LEGACY characters dead (like seriously tho, IN THE FRICKEN TRAILER!?!?) just because you wanted to show/spoil a cool little easter egg for nostalgia points... I have been a fan of this franchise since I was a little girl. While all of the other kids I grew up around were watching Love and Basketball, I was watching Terminator, Halloween,  and Nightmare on Elm Street. Lol. I think the only halloween films I absolutely hate are Resurrection and Rob Zombies Halloween 2 (that was utter garbage)...and I only care for Zombie's theatrical version of Halloween (2007), the unrated version has a very unnecessary and misplaced rape scene in it that made ZERO sense.  As much as I love the OG Halloween films, I think it's safe to say that they did complicate the story with that "curse of thorn" thing in an attempt to explain why Michael was so evil. To this day, no matter how much googling I do, I still cannot find a clear explanation on that.  I love with these new films (as well as H20, although that one no longer exists in this timeline) they went back to the basics and kept things simple. A lot of people gave Halloween 2018 flack, which I don't get... because lately horror has been a trash show of over-played found footage, repetitive demon crap (honestly, let The Conjuring go already), and ridiculous PG-13 90's wannabe films with way too much overstated, in-your-face political undertones.  True Halloween fans will remember that the very first Halloween film was shot with a low budget, wasn't all that bloody, relied on shadows and natural sounds to set the tones for scenes, and they even had to use people from the crew sometimes to stand in for certain scenes. True horror films tell stories, not just play off gore porn and overused supernatural storylines.  What makes Halloween stand out in horror is that over 40 years (since the original one), it has manged to re-invent itself with every film (even in the dumb ones lol).  I'm so ready for this film I sat here and typed an entire excerpt about it. ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ Anywho, see yall at the theaters!!

Halloween has always been my favorite franchise and Michael Mers has always been my "boogeyman."  I hated the Rob Zombie ones because they replaced suspense with gore.  The fear came from not knowing where he was.  He was a silent, relentless, and deadly force.  In the RZ movies he just showed up and stabbed everyone a million times.  NO suspense at all.  But to his credit Rob added new backstory and depth that hadn't been there before.  this new trilogy seems to be the best of both worlds.  It brought back Jamie Lee Curtis to really delve into how something like that would effect a person for the rest of their lives, but also brought back suspense and "edge of your seat" thrills for the purists.  I can't freaking wait for october.  I just wish it was this year
